docs.lead_paragraph: Insurers aren't required to encrypt consumers' data under a 1990s federal law that remains the foundation for health care privacy in the Internet age — an omission that seems striking in light of the major cyberattack against Anthem.

headline.main: No Encryption Standard Raises Health Care Privacy Questions
headline.print_headline: No Encryption Standard Raises Health Care Privacy Questions

docs.snippet: Insurers aren't required to encrypt consumers' data under a 1990s federal law that remains the foundation for health care privacy in the Internet age — an omission that seems striking in light of the major cyberattack against Anthem.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical identify theft has become a booming business, according to security experts, who warn that other health care companies are likely to be targets.

headline.main: Data Breach at Anthem May Forecast a Trend
headline.print_headline: Data Breach at Anthem May Augur a Trend

docs.abstract: Computer security experts warn that successful data breach of Anthem, largest in health care industry, will likely lead hackers to target other large insurers as medical identity theft has become booming business; Anthem hack has already resulted in proliferation of email scams; question of whether data breach was work of independent actors or if it was state-sponsored espionage remains unresolved.
docs.snippet: Medical identify theft has become a booming business, according to security experts, who warn that other health care companies are likely to be targets.

byline.contributor: Tara Siegel Bernard, Matthew Goldstein and David E. Sanger contributed reporting.
byline.original: By REED ABELSON and JULIE CRESWELL

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Nunnelee, a fiscal and social conservative, was first elected to Congress in the Republican wave of 2010.

headline.main: Alan Nunnelee, G.O.P. House Member From Mississippi, Dies at 56

docs.abstract: Alan Nunnelee, Republican Representative from Mississippi elected to Congress in 2010, dies at age 56.
docs.snippet: Mr. Nunnelee, a fiscal and social conservative, was first elected to Congress in the Republican wave of 2010.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumers can take steps to protect themselves and their medical information after a hacking attack like that on Anthem Health.

headline.main: What Anthem Customers Should Do Next After Data Breach

docs.snippet: Consumers can take steps to protect themselves and their medical information after a hacking attack like that on Anthem Health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Baby boomers are turning to the growing number of firms that specialize in placing older workers in part-time or temporary positions in specific industries.

headline.main: Consulting as a Bridge Between Full-Time Work and Retirement
headline.print_headline: Consulting as a Bridge Between Full-Time Work and Retirement

docs.abstract: Retiring column; some baby boomers who are intent on phasing into retirement are exploring possibility of working as consultants in fields in which they have experience, which will offer them a bridge job before retiring; such positions offer workers flexibility in hours but allow them to continue getting income.
docs.snippet: Baby boomers are turning to the growing number of firms that specialize in placing older workers in part-time or temporary positions in specific industries.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the same test is reimbursed more when done by a hospital, it gives doctors a reason to go work for hospitals.

headline.main: When Hospitals Buy Doctors’ Offices, and Patient Fees Soar

docs.snippet: When the same test is reimbursed more when done by a hospital, it gives doctors a reason to go work for hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The introduction of municipal identification cards, one of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s signature initiatives, has been anything but smooth.

headline.main: New Yorkers Clamor for IDs, Swamping Mayor’s Key Project
headline.print_headline: New Yorkers Clamor for IDs, Swamping Mayor’s Key Project

docs.abstract: New York City officials announce that they are finally catching up with demand for municipal identity cards, initiative that has been hobbled by system overwhelmed with applications received since it began Jan 12, 2015; city designed system, which is one of Mayor Bill de Blasio's signature policy initiatives, to handle 300,000 applications a year, but 218,000 appointments have been made to date.
docs.snippet: The introduction of municipal identification cards, one of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s signature initiatives, has been anything but smooth.

docs.lead_paragraph: American employers added 257,000 jobs in January, showing that signs of economic momentum late last year carried into 2015.

headline.main: Amid Gains in Jobs and Pay, Americans Rejoin the Work Force
headline.print_headline: Job Count Finds Best 3 Months Since Late 1990s

docs.abstract: Labor Department revises upward estimates of job gains in 2014 in November and December, adding additional 147,000 jobs, which brings number of jobs created in 2014 to total that is higher than any year since 1999; department reports employers added seasonally adjusted 257,00 jobs in January; uptick in employment, if it persists, could affect political debate in run up to 2016 presidential election, although analysts are uncertain that wage growth can be sustained.
docs.snippet: American employers added 257,000 jobs in January, showing that signs of economic momentum late last year carried into 2015.

docs.lead_paragraph: The hackers who stole millions of health insurance records from Anthem Inc. commandeered the credentials of five different employees while seeking to penetrate the company's computer network — and they may have been inside the system since December.

headline.main: Anthem: Hackers Tried to Breach System as Early as Dec. 10
headline.print_headline: Anthem: Hackers Tried to Breach System as Early as Dec. 10
